title: Jeremiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 36 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 36.

questions.question: In which year of Jehoiakim's reign did the word come to Jeremiah from the LORD?
options: Fourth year
First year
Fifth year
Tenth year
questions.correctAnswer: Fourth year
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:1 states that the word came to Jeremiah in the fourth year of Jehoiakim's reign.

questions.question: Who was commanded by Jeremiah to write down all the words spoken to him by the LORD?
options: Baruch the son of Neriah
Jehudi the son of Nethaniah
Gemariah the son of Shaphan
Elishama the scribe
questions.correctAnswer: Baruch the son of Neriah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:4 tells us that Jeremiah called Baruch to write all the words of the LORD.

questions.question: Why was Jeremiah unable to go into the house of the LORD himself?
options: He was shut up
He was sick
He was on a journey
He was forbidden by the king
questions.correctAnswer: He was shut up
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 36:5 Jeremiah says he is shut up and cannot go into the house of the LORD.

questions.question: On what occasion was Baruch instructed to read the words of the LORD to the people?
options: On the fasting day
During the feast of Passover
On the Sabbath
During the new moon festival
questions.correctAnswer: On the fasting day
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:6 commands Baruch to read the words of the LORD on the fasting day.

questions.question: Where did Baruch read the words of Jeremiah in the house of the LORD?
options: In the chamber of Gemariah, at the entry of the new gate
In the main sanctuary
At the altar
In the king's chamber
questions.correctAnswer: In the chamber of Gemariah, at the entry of the new gate
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:10 describes that Baruch read in the chamber of Gemariah, at the entry of the new gate of the LORD's house.

questions.question: Who heard the words from the book and then reported them to the princes?
options: Michaiah the son of Gemariah
Jehudi the son of Nethaniah
Baruch the son of Neriah
Elishama the scribe
questions.correctAnswer: Michaiah the son of Gemariah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:11-13 tells us Michaiah heard the words and declared them to the princes.

questions.question: What did the princes do after hearing the words from the scroll read by Baruch?
options: Sent Jehudi to bring the scroll to them
Burned the scroll immediately
Ignored the message
Sent Jeremiah away
questions.correctAnswer: Sent Jehudi to bring the scroll to them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:14 says the princes sent Jehudi to Baruch to bring the scroll to them.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the princes after hearing all the words read from the scroll?
options: They were afraid and decided to tell the king
They rejoiced and praised the LORD
They challenged Jeremiah
They destroyed the scroll
questions.correctAnswer: They were afraid and decided to tell the king
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:16 states that the princes were afraid and said they would tell the king all these words.

questions.question: How did Baruch write down all the words spoken by Jeremiah?
options: He wrote them with ink in the book as Jeremiah pronounced
He memorized and later wrote them down
He wrote them from memory after the reading
He used stones to carve the words
questions.correctAnswer: He wrote them with ink in the book as Jeremiah pronounced
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:18 explains that Baruch wrote all the words with ink in the book as Jeremiah pronounced them.

questions.question: What did the king do after Jehudi read part of the scroll to him?
options: He cut the scroll with a penknife and burned it
He ordered Jeremiah to be arrested immediately
He praised the message
He sent the scroll to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: He cut the scroll with a penknife and burned it
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:23 describes how the king cut the scroll and burned it in the fire.

questions.question: True or False: The king and his servants tore their garments after hearing the words from the scroll.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:24 states that neither the king nor his servants were afraid or tore their garments after hearing the words.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD hid Jeremiah and Baruch when the king commanded their arrest.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:26 confirms that the LORD hid Jeremiah and Baruch from the king’s men.

questions.question: True or False: After the first scroll was burned, the LORD told Jeremiah to write a new scroll with the same words and many more.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:28 and 36:32 tell that Jeremiah wrote another scroll with the same words and additional similar words.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Thou hast burned this roll, saying, Why hast thou written therein, saying, The king of Babylon shall _______?'
options: certainly come and destroy this land
come and be defeated
build a great temple
return to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: certainly come and destroy this land
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:29 records the king’s words accusing Jeremiah of writing that the king of Babylon would come and destroy the land.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 36:30, what will happen to Jehoiakim king of Judah?
options: He will have none to sit upon the throne of David
He will reign peacefully for many years
He will conquer Babylon
He will be made a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: He will have none to sit upon the throne of David
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:30 states that Jehoiakim will have none to sit on the throne of David and his body will be cast out.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 36 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement because they feel their prayers are unanswered. Based on Jeremiah 36:3 and 36:7, what biblical truth would you share about prayer and repentance?
options: God's anger is fixed and cannot be changed by prayer.
Prayer and repentance can lead to forgiveness and turning away from evil.
Prayers must be done in secret to be effective.
Only the king can intercede to change God's mind.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer and repentance can lead to forgiveness and turning away from evil.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:3 and 36:7 emphasize that God’s purpose in revealing his words is so that Judah may hear, repent, and return to Him, leading to forgiveness. Prayer and supplication are means for God's people to receive mercy.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 36 teach us about obedience and faithfulness in sharing God's Word, even when facing personal difficulty?
options: Jeremiah refused to speak because he was afraid.
Baruch faithfully wrote and read the words despite Jeremiah's inability to attend the temple.
They hid the scroll and did not share it with the people.
They only shared the message with the king.
questions.correctAnswer: Baruch faithfully wrote and read the words despite Jeremiah's inability to attend the temple.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:4-6 shows Jeremiah commanded Baruch to write down and read the words because Jeremiah himself was shut up and could not go to the temple, illustrating obedience and faithfulness in difficult circumstances.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 36:9-10, what role does corporate fasting and gathering together play in spiritual discipline and revival?
options: Fasting is only for individual prayer, not for public gatherings.
Fasting and public reading of God's Word can prompt collective repentance and hearing God's message.
Fasting should be done secretly without informing others.
Gathering is unnecessary if the king is opposed.
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting and public reading of God's Word can prompt collective repentance and hearing God's message.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:9-10 records a proclaimed fast where Baruch read the words publicly, showing that spiritual discipline through fasting and hearing the Word together is important for revival and repentance.

questions.question: A church leader is hesitant to share difficult prophetic messages. Based on Jeremiah 36:14-15, what encouragement can you offer about faithfully delivering God's Word?
options: Only positive messages should be shared.
Baruch read the entire scroll openly to the princes, showing courage and obedience.
Prophetic messages should be hidden from leaders.
The Word should be altered to please authorities.
questions.correctAnswer: Baruch read the entire scroll openly to the princes, showing courage and obedience.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:14-15 shows Baruch obeyed Jeremiah's command and read the full message to the princes, demonstrating the importance of courageously delivering God's Word despite the consequences.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 36:16-19 teach about integrity and trust in God's protection when facing opposition for sharing His Word?
options: The princes encouraged Jeremiah and Baruch to hide for their safety, showing trust in God's protection.
Jeremiah and Baruch fled without support.
They denied the message to avoid danger.
They bribed officials for protection.
questions.correctAnswer: The princes encouraged Jeremiah and Baruch to hide for their safety, showing trust in God's protection.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:19 records the princes advising Baruch and Jeremiah to hide, and Jeremiah 36:26 confirms God hid them, illustrating integrity in obedience and trust in divine protection amid threats.

questions.question: How does the king's reaction in Jeremiah 36:21-24 challenge believers in their response to God's Word?
options: The king was fearful and repented immediately.
The king burned the scroll but was not afraid or repentant.
The king rewarded Jeremiah for the message.
The king ignored the message and continued worship.
questions.correctAnswer: The king burned the scroll but was not afraid or repentant.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:23-24 shows that Jehoiakim burned the scroll containing God's word but neither he nor his servants showed fear or repentance, challenging believers to respond with humility and seriousness to God's message.

questions.question: What lesson about perseverance through trials can we learn from Jeremiah 36:27-32 after the scroll was burned by the king?
options: Jeremiah gave up after the scroll was burned.
Jeremiah rewrote the scroll with even more words, showing perseverance.
Baruch refused to write again.
They stopped delivering the message temporarily.
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah rewrote the scroll with even more words, showing perseverance.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:27-32 illustrates perseverance and faithfulness as Jeremiah rewrote the entire message despite opposition, encouraging believers to continue in God’s work despite setbacks.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was physically able to enter the house of the LORD and read the scroll himself during the fasting day.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:5 states that Jeremiah was shut up and could not go into the house of the LORD, so he commanded Baruch to read the scroll instead.

questions.question: True or False: The king of Judah heeded the warnings in the scroll and repented after hearing the words of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:24-25 and 36:31 show that the king and his servants did not fear or repent despite hearing the words, and judgment was pronounced against them.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Jeremiah 36:2, Jeremiah was instructed to write all the words spoken by the LORD against Israel, Judah, and all the __________.
options: cities
armies
nations
kings
questions.correctAnswer: nations
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:2 directs Jeremiah to write the words spoken against Israel, Judah, and all the nations, indicating the scope of God's message.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 36:6-7 encourage believers to be witnesses and evangelists in their communities?
options: Only priests are allowed to share God’s Word publicly.
Baruch was commanded to read the words publicly in the temple and throughout Judah, encouraging widespread witness.
The message was only for the king and his court.
Sharing God’s Word publicly was forbidden.
questions.correctAnswer: Baruch was commanded to read the words publicly in the temple and throughout Judah, encouraging widespread witness.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:6-7 commands Baruch to read the scroll in the temple on the fasting day and in the cities of Judah, demonstrating the importance of public witness and evangelism.

questions.question: In light of Jeremiah 36:20-22, what does the king’s setting and reaction tell us about the dangers of complacency in spiritual matters?
options: The king was attentive and sought counsel.
The king was relaxed in his winterhouse by the fire and showed no fear when the scroll was read, indicating complacency.
The king immediately repented during the reading.
The king was angry and ordered immediate action.
questions.correctAnswer: The king was relaxed in his winterhouse by the fire and showed no fear when the scroll was read, indicating complacency.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:20-22 depicts the king sitting comfortably in his winterhouse by the fire, not fearing the words of the scroll, illustrating complacency despite serious warnings.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 36:18 highlight the importance of accurate and faithful recording of God’s Word in ministry?
options: Baruch made up some of the words to please the king.
Baruch wrote exactly what Jeremiah pronounced with ink in the book, showing faithful transcription.
Jeremiah wrote the scroll himself without help.
The words were memorized but not written down.
questions.correctAnswer: Baruch wrote exactly what Jeremiah pronounced with ink in the book, showing faithful transcription.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:18 confirms Baruch’s role in faithfully and accurately writing the words spoken by Jeremiah, underscoring integrity in ministry.

questions.question: What biblical virtue related to leadership can be learned from the intercession of Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah in Jeremiah 36:25?
options: They silently accepted the king’s decision.
They boldly interceded to prevent the burning of the scroll, showing courage and concern for God’s Word.
They conspired against Jeremiah and Baruch.
They encouraged the king to burn the scroll.
questions.correctAnswer: They boldly interceded to prevent the burning of the scroll, showing courage and concern for God’s Word.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:25 highlights the intercession of these princes attempting to stop the king, teaching the value of courageous leadership and advocacy for God’s truth.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 36:29-30, what warning does God give to those who reject His Word and oppose His message?
options: They will be honored by future generations.
They will have no lasting legacy and will face judgment.
They will be promoted to higher office.
They will escape punishment if they repent later.
questions.correctAnswer: They will have no lasting legacy and will face judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:29-30 pronounces that Jehoiakim will have no one to sit on David’s throne and his body will be exposed to heat and frost, symbolizing judgment for rejecting God's Word.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 36.

questions.question: Who was commanded by the LORD to write the words spoken to Jeremiah according to Jeremiah 36?
options: Baruch the son of Neriah
Jehudi the son of Nethaniah
Micaiah the son of Gemariah
Elishama the scribe
questions.correctAnswer: Baruch the son of Neriah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:4 states that Baruch the son of Neriah wrote all the words of the LORD as spoken to Jeremiah.

questions.question: What was the intended purpose of writing down the words of the LORD as expressed in Jeremiah 36:3?
options: That the house of Judah might hear and return from their evil ways
To condemn the nations without possibility of repentance
To glorify the king of Judah
To record historical events for the future
questions.correctAnswer: That the house of Judah might hear and return from their evil ways
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:3 explains that the writing was so Judah might hear the evil God purposes and return from their evil ways for forgiveness.

questions.question: During which king's reign did the LORD give Jeremiah the command to write the words on a scroll?
options: Jehoiakim
Josiah
Zedekiah
Manasseh
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiakim
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:1 specifies that this command came in the fourth year of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah.

questions.question: Where did Baruch read the words of Jeremiah in the presence of the people and princes?
options: In the LORD's house in the chamber of Gemariah
In the king's palace throne room
At the city gates
In the court of the priests
questions.correctAnswer: In the LORD's house in the chamber of Gemariah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:10 describes Baruch reading the words in the LORD's house, specifically in the chamber of Gemariah the son of Shaphan.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the princes after hearing the words read from the scroll?
options: They were afraid and said they would tell the king
They rejoiced and praised the LORD
They ignored the message
They immediately repented and fasted
questions.correctAnswer: They were afraid and said they would tell the king
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:16 states that after hearing all the words, the princes were afraid and decided to report them to the king.

questions.question: What did King Jehoiakim do to the scroll after hearing part of its contents?
options: He cut it with a penknife and burned it in the fire
He stored it carefully in the royal archives
He ordered it copied for distribution
He hid it away secretly
questions.correctAnswer: He cut it with a penknife and burned it in the fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:23 describes how King Jehoiakim cut the scroll with a penknife and threw it into the fire until the entire scroll was consumed.

questions.question: Which individuals pleaded with the king not to burn the scroll?
options: Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah
Jehudi, Baruch, and Jeremiah
Micaiah, Jehudi, and Elishama
Zedekiah, Gemariah, and Michaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:25 records that Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah interceded with the king to spare the scroll, but he refused.

questions.question: What was the LORD's instruction to Jeremiah after King Jehoiakim burned the original scroll?
options: Take another scroll and write all the former words again
Stop prophesying to Judah
Flee to Egypt immediately
Appeal directly to the king for mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Take another scroll and write all the former words again
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:28 commands Jeremiah to take another scroll and rewrite all the words that were on the first scroll that was burned.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 36:29, what reason did Jehoiakim give for burning the scroll?
options: He questioned why the scroll prophesied Babylon’s destruction of the land
He believed it was a forgery
He wanted to protect the people from fear
He thought it was too long and tedious
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned why the scroll prophesied Babylon’s destruction of the land
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:29 records that Jehoiakim burned the scroll saying, 'Why have you written that the king of Babylon will destroy this land?'

questions.question: What prophecy concerning Jehoiakim does the LORD declare after the burning of the scroll?
options: He shall have no one to sit on the throne of David and his body will be exposed to heat and frost
He shall reign in peace and prosperity
He shall defeat Babylon and reign forever
He shall be taken captive but later restored
questions.correctAnswer: He shall have no one to sit on the throne of David and his body will be exposed to heat and frost
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:30 prophesies that Jehoiakim will have no successor on David's throne and his dead body will be exposed to the elements.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 36:26 tell us about the fate of Jeremiah and Baruch when the king ordered their arrest?
options: The LORD hid them so they were not found
They were imprisoned immediately
They fled to Babylon
They were publicly humiliated
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD hid them so they were not found
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:26 says that when the king commanded their arrest, the LORD hid Jeremiah and Baruch so no one knew where they were.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah personally read the scroll aloud to the people on the fasting day in the LORD’s house.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:6 and 36:8 show that Baruch read the words in the LORD’s house because Jeremiah was shut up and could not go in.

questions.question: When Jehudi read the scroll to King Jehoiakim, what was the king’s reaction?
options: He cut and burned the scroll without fear or mourning
He tore his garments and repented
He immediately ordered the scroll hidden
He praised Jeremiah’s prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: He cut and burned the scroll without fear or mourning
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:23-24 explain that the king cut the scroll and burned it, showing no fear or mourning.

questions.question: Which literary device is exemplified by the cycle of writing the scroll, its destruction by fire, and rewriting it again in Jeremiah 36?
options: Typology of prophetic resilience
Chiasm illustrating divine judgment
Parallelism between kings
Allegory of Babylonian captivity
questions.correctAnswer: Typology of prophetic resilience
questions.explanation: The destruction and rewriting of the scroll typify the persistence of God's prophetic word despite human opposition, showing prophetic resilience.

questions.question: The burning of the scroll by King Jehoiakim foreshadows which major biblical event?
options: The Babylonian exile and destruction of Jerusalem
The rebuilding of the temple under Ezra
The establishment of the Davidic kingdom
The Babylonian defeat by Persia
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile and destruction of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The scroll’s prophecy about Babylon’s destruction and Jehoiakim’s rejection foreshadow the exile and destruction of Jerusalem described elsewhere in the Bible.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 36 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary purpose of Jeremiah writing down the words spoken to him by the LORD as described in Jeremiah 36?
options: To warn the house of Judah so they might repent and be forgiven
To create a historical record for future generations
To prove Jeremiah's prophetic authority
To show the king's power over Judah
questions.correctAnswer: To warn the house of Judah so they might repent and be forgiven
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:3 states the purpose was that Judah might hear the evil God purposed, return from their evil ways, and receive forgiveness. This aligns with God's calls to repentance in Ezekiel 18:21-23, 2 Chronicles 7:14, Jonah 3:4-10, and Acts 3:19.

questions.question: Who was instructed by Jeremiah to write down the words of the LORD on the roll of the book?
options: Baruch the son of Neriah
Micaiah the son of Gemariah
Jehudi the son of Nethaniah
Elishama the scribe
questions.correctAnswer: Baruch the son of Neriah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:4 records that Baruch wrote from Jeremiah's mouth all the words of the LORD. This shows the role of prophetic scribes similar to Ezra in Ezra 7:6 and the amanuensis role in writing apostolic letters as in 1 Corinthians 16:21.

questions.question: Why did Jeremiah command Baruch to read the words of the LORD on the fasting day in the house of the LORD and in the cities of Judah?
options: So the people might present supplication and repent
To challenge the king's authority publicly
To celebrate a festival
To teach the scribes how to write
questions.correctAnswer: So the people might present supplication and repent
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:6-7 explains the intent was that the people might pray and turn from evil because of the LORD's great anger. This reflects the biblical pattern of corporate repentance in Joel 2:12-17, Nehemiah 9:1-3, and Acts 2:38.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the princes after hearing the words from the scroll read by Baruch?
options: They were afraid and decided to inform the king
They praised the LORD for His mercy
They immediately repented and confessed their sins
They dismissed the message as irrelevant
questions.correctAnswer: They were afraid and decided to inform the king
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:16 shows the princes were afraid and resolved to tell the king all the words. Fear of God's word and judgment is a consistent biblical theme, as seen in Exodus 19:16-25, Isaiah 6:5, Hebrews 12:28-29, and Revelation 1:17.

questions.question: How did King Jehoiakim respond when Jehudi read the words from the scroll to him?
options: He cut the scroll with a penknife and burned it
He repented and sought the LORD
He praised Jeremiah for his faithfulness
He ordered the scroll to be copied and distributed
questions.correctAnswer: He cut the scroll with a penknife and burned it
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:23 records that the king cut the scroll and burned it on the hearth. This act symbolizes rejection of God's word and is comparable to Pharaoh hardening his heart in Exodus 7:13, King Saul rejecting Samuel's prophecy in 1 Samuel 15:10-11, and Herod's opposition in Acts 12:1-4.

questions.question: What was the LORD's instruction to Jeremiah after King Jehoiakim burned the scroll?
options: Write another scroll with the same words and add more
Stop prophesying to Judah
Go into hiding and cease all public readings
Appeal to the king for mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Write another scroll with the same words and add more
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:28-32 commands Jeremiah to write another scroll with the words that were burned and add many similar words. This shows God's sovereignty over human rejection and parallels the renewal of the covenant in Deuteronomy 31:24-26 and Paul's perseverance in 2 Timothy 4:2-5.

questions.question: What was the prophecy concerning King Jehoiakim found in the words Jeremiah was commanded to write again?
options: He shall have no one to sit on David's throne, and his dead body will be exposed to heat and frost
He will reign in peace and prosperity
He will conquer Babylon and expand his kingdom
He will be remembered as a righteous king
questions.correctAnswer: He shall have no one to sit on David's throne, and his dead body will be exposed to heat and frost
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:30 prophesies Jehoiakim's dishonorable death and the end of his dynasty. This judgment reflects God's justice and is consistent with the Davidic covenant warnings in 2 Samuel 7:12-16, Psalm 89:30-37, and the downfall of kings in 1 Kings 11:11-13.

questions.question: What divine attribute is demonstrated by the LORD hiding Jeremiah and Baruch when the king commanded their arrest?
options: God's providence and protection of His servants
God's indifference to human affairs
God's inability to intervene in political matters
God's preference for secrecy over revelation
questions.correctAnswer: God's providence and protection of His servants
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:26 states the LORD hid Jeremiah and Baruch from arrest, demonstrating His providential care. This is consistent with divine protection seen in Daniel 6:22, Psalm 34:7, Acts 12:6-11, and Isaiah 41:10.

questions.question: What theological lesson about human sin and divine judgment is illustrated by Jehoiakim's rejection and burning of the scroll?
options: Rejection of God's word leads to inevitable judgment and loss of covenant blessing
Ignoring prophecy has no consequences
God's judgment is arbitrary and unpredictable
Prophecy is optional for God's people
questions.correctAnswer: Rejection of God's word leads to inevitable judgment and loss of covenant blessing
questions.explanation: Jehoiakim's burning of the scroll (Jeremiah 36:23-25) symbolizes rejection of God's covenantal warnings, resulting in judgment (36:30-31). This principle is affirmed in Hebrews 2:1-4, Deuteronomy 28, and John 12:48.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 36 demonstrate the role of the prophetic word in calling God's people to repentance?
options: The prophetic word is a call to hear, repent, and seek forgiveness
The prophetic word is only for predicting the future
The prophetic word is meant to entertain the people
The prophetic word is irrelevant to the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The prophetic word is a call to hear, repent, and seek forgiveness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:3, 6-7 emphasize that the written and read words were to lead Judah to repentance and forgiveness. This aligns with the prophetic calling in Isaiah 1:18, Ezekiel 33:11, and Luke 24:46-47.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 36 reveal about God's justice and patience towards a sinful nation?
options: God patiently warns and provides opportunity for repentance before judgment
God immediately punishes without warning
God ignores sin and lets it continue
God's justice is impartial and unchanging but without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God patiently warns and provides opportunity for repentance before judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 3, 7, and 31 show God warning Judah of impending punishment to encourage repentance, demonstrating His patience and justice. This is consistent with 2 Peter 3:9, Ezekiel 18:23, and Romans 2:4.

questions.question: What does the presence of scribes and princes listening to the scroll being read indicate about the role of leadership in responding to God's word?
options: Leaders are responsible for hearing and responding to God's revelation
Leaders are exempt from God's word
Leaders only enforce civil laws, not divine commands
Leaders should ignore prophetic messages
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders are responsible for hearing and responding to God's revelation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:12-15 shows princes and scribes hearing the word, signifying their role in mediation and accountability. This corresponds with 1 Timothy 3:1-7, Proverbs 29:2, and Hebrews 13:17 regarding leadership responsibility.

questions.question: What eschatological theme is reflected in the prophecy against Jehoiakim and the coming destruction by Babylon?
options: God's sovereign judgment brings an end to rebellion and ushers in covenant renewal
The world will be destroyed without warning
God's people will never face judgment
The king's reign will continue forever
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign judgment brings an end to rebellion and ushers in covenant renewal
questions.explanation: The prophecy of destruction (Jeremiah 36:29-31) reflects God's sovereign judgment against covenant unfaithfulness, foreshadowing the exile and eventual restoration. This echoes Revelation 20:11-15, Daniel 7:9-14, Isaiah 65:17-25, and Romans 11:26-27.

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the interplay between divine sovereignty and human responsibility?
options: God sends prophetic warnings, but humans must choose to repent or face judgment
God forces humans to obey without choice
Humans have full control and God does not intervene
Prophets act independently without God's direction
questions.correctAnswer: God sends prophetic warnings, but humans must choose to repent or face judgment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36 shows God commanding Jeremiah to write and command repentance, yet Jehoiakim freely rejects the word and faces judgment. This dynamic is seen in Joshua 24:15, Deuteronomy 30:19, Ezekiel 18:30-32, and Galatians 6:7-8.

questions.question: What does the act of writing and reading the scroll publicly signify about the nature of God's revelation?
options: God's word is to be openly proclaimed and accessible to all people
God's word is secret and only for priests
God's word is symbolic and not literal
God's word is only for kings
questions.correctAnswer: God's word is to be openly proclaimed and accessible to all people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 36:6, 10 describe public reading of the scroll in the temple and cities, indicating God's revelation is meant for the entire community. This parallels Deuteronomy 31:11-13, Nehemiah 8:2-8, Luke 4:16-21, and Revelation 1:3.
